channel.title: Windows On 1 HD Linux On Another [Questions]
channel.description:
I'm not partitioning. I've seen a lot of articles saying it can be pretty risky. Also, with space running out on my desktop HD, I thought, why not get a new one for Linux.
So: On the Ubuntu set up screen, does it give me the choice of where to put Ubuntu? HD 2 If I want a file I have on Windows, to go on to HD 2, is it just a matter of drag and drop? When Ubuntu is installed, will I get the choice of which OS I log in to when I turn my PC on? (If HD 2 is plugged in)
Any other information needed about installing on a second HD?

item.dc:creator: @regecks1 regecks`
item.description:
@regecks1 wrote:

IMO USE YOUR ORIGINAL THREAD.

I've seen a lot of articles saying it can be pretty risky
Written by idiots, for idiots. Partitioning is perfectly fine as long as you're not completely retarded and delete your existing ones.

So on that wonderful website called Google, I found a nice guide to installing Ubuntu, which can be found here: http://psychocats.net/ubuntu/installing

Here it shows what will happen when it asks you to choose what drive to use:

You can either:

  1. Erase your “new” hard drive and let it use all of it for your Ubuntu.
  2. “Resize” your existing hard drive partitions to use Ubuntu.
  3. Manually edit (probably not for you).

As for your other questions:

The Ubuntu installer will install some sort of booter such as GRUB or LILO, which will allow you to select between Windows and Ubuntu.

To read Windows files, you will need to setup Ubuntu to be able to mount NTFS partitions, and simple mount your Windows partitions during Ubuntu. There is an abundance of tutorials on this.
